term_definitions.items: Metadata for a document attachment, using UK GP2GP metadata definition.
Unique Document identifier generated by originator.
Uniques document set identifier generated by the originator.
The version number (integer) of the document.

Inclusion of this element will enable identification of the document's persistent and unique filename that consists of the document.id GUID plus the document.filenameextension (for a list of recommended and black listed file types see NPFIT-FNT-TO-TAR-0095.02 CDA Documents - Attachment Types v1.0.docx for a list of file types).
Unique Document identifier of a document which this document has replaced.

he SNOMED CT subsets 'Care setting' and 'Document type' were released in the April 2012 SNOMED CT release. Examples of Care setting are Gynaecology, OOH, A+E etc. and examples of Document type are Discharge Summary Report, Referral letter etc. The clinical requirement is for this combination of subset elements to be coded so that a) a meaningful name can be made available for display to the user and b) the combination can be easily processed to support document management (e.g. categorising, sorting, searching etc). There are various ways that this requirement could be met including the use of a Post coordinated SNOMED CT expression. Within a General Practice setting, the way in which a document display name encoded with 'Care setting' and 'Document type' is to be displayed has been specified by the GP clinical community and can be found with the 'Document Ontology and Metadata - Supplier Guidance' document issued by NHS CFH.
SNOMED CT code from 'Document Type' SCT subset.
SNOMED CT code from 'Care Setting' SCT subset.
Text description of document. This is independent of the combined term resulting from a combination of the terms associated with document.type and document.caresetting.
The date / time that the original document was created.
This indicates the 'sensitivity' of the whole document.
Normal confidentiality rules. Only authorized individuals with a legitimate medical or business need may access this item.
Restricted access. Access is restricted to providers having a current care relationship to the patient
Very restricited access. As determined by the Privacy Officer of the record holder.
Name and role of the person who attested to the accuracy of the document. An example would be the name of the clinician who saw the patient, wrote a document and then later signed it.
Details of the document's sending organisation, including the Id, name and department.
Details of the person receiving the document.
Details of the organisation receiving the document.
Details of the patient to whom the document pertains, including Id, name, address and date of birth.
Date / time of event which caused the document to be created.
Length of time the referral is valid.
Duration for which the referral is valid.
If true, referral is for an indefinite period of time.
A list of people or organisations who are relevant to this referral, including next of kin.
Generic request for a range of different healthcare services e.g referral, lab request, equipment request.
Request for provision of a specified service by another healthcare provider or organisation.
The local ID assigned to the order by the healthcare provider or organisation requesting the service. This is also referred to as Placer Order Identifier.
The ID assigned to the order by the healthcare provider or organisation receiving the request for service. This is also referred to as Filler Order Identifier.
The date and time that the service should be performed or completed.
A short description of the reason for the request. This is often coded with an external terminology.
A narrative description explaining the reason for request.
Stated intent of the request by the referrer.
True indicates that additional information has been identified and will be forwarded when available eg incomplete pathology test results.
Details of the nature of supplementary information that is to follow e.g name of laboratory results.
Local detailed information such as billing requirements.
Language, transport or other personal requirements to support the patient's attendance or participation in provision of the service.
Identification of the service requested. This is often coded with an external terminology.

The status of the request for service as indicated by the requester. Status is used to denote whether this is the initial request, or a follow-up request to change or provide supplementary information.
A list of people or organisation who should receive copies of any communication.
Structured detail defining the service requested eg CLUSTER archetype specifying the specific catheter that is to be inserted.
A detailed narrative description of the service requested.
Details about the healthcare provider or organisation requesting the service.
Details about the healthcare provider or organisation receiving the request for service.
The latest date that is acceptable for the service to be completed.
Length of time the referral is valid.
Duration for which the referral is valid.
If true, referral is for an indefinite period of time.
A list of people or organisations who are relevant to this referral, including next of kin.
Generic request for a range of different healthcare services e.g referral, lab request, equipment request.
Request for provision of a specified service by another healthcare provider or organisation.
The local ID assigned to the order by the healthcare provider or organisation requesting the service. This is also referred to as Placer Order Identifier.
The ID assigned to the order by the healthcare provider or organisation receiving the request for service. This is also referred to as Filler Order Identifier.
The date and time that the service should be performed or completed.
A short description of the reason for the request. This is often coded with an external terminology.
A narrative description explaining the reason for request.
Stated intent of the request by the referrer.
True indicates that additional information has been identified and will be forwarded when available eg incomplete pathology test results.
Details of the nature of supplementary information that is to follow e.g name of laboratory results.
Local detailed information such as billing requirements.
Language, transport or other personal requirements to support the patient's attendance or participation in provision of the service.
Identification of the service requested. This is often coded with an external terminology.

The status of the request for service as indicated by the requester. Status is used to denote whether this is the initial request, or a follow-up request to change or provide supplementary information.
A list of people or organisation who should receive copies of any communication.
Structured detail defining the service requested eg CLUSTER archetype specifying the specific catheter that is to be inserted.
A detailed narrative description of the service requested.
Details about the healthcare provider or organisation requesting the service.
Details about the healthcare provider or organisation receiving the request for service.
The latest date that is acceptable for the service to be completed.
The reason for initiation of any healthcare encounter or contact by the individual who is the subject of care.

Coding of the 'Contact type' with a terminology is desirable, where possible. Examples include: pre-employment medical, routine antenatal visit, women's health check, pre-operative assessment, or annual medical check-up.
Identification of the type, or administrative category, of healthcare sought or required by the subject of care.

Coding of the 'Presenting problem' with a terminology is desirable, where possible. Clinical or social reasons for seeking healthcare can include health issues, symptoms or physical signs. Examples: health issues - desire to quit smoking, domestic violence; symptoms - abdominal pain, shortness of breath; physical signs - an altered conscious state. 'Chief complaint' may be used as a valid synonym for 'Presenting problem' in templates.
Identification of the clinical or social problem motivating the subject of care to seeking healthcare.
The subjective clinical history of the subject of care as recorded directly by the subject, or reported to a clinician by the subject or a carer.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Narrative description of the story or clinical history for the subject of care.
For example: a specific symptom such as nausea or pain; an event such as a fall off a bicycle; or an issue such as a desire to quit using tobacco.
Structured detail about the individual's story or patient's history.
For example: Local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.

Clear delineation between the scope of a problem versus a diagnosis is not easy to achieve in practice. For the purposes of clinical documentation with this archetype, problem and diagnosis are regarded as a continuum, with increasing levels of detail and supportive evidence usually providing weight towards the label of 'diagnosis'.
Details about a single identified health condition, injury or issue which impacts on the physical, mental and/or social well-being of an individual.
Coding of the name of the problem or diagnosis with a terminology is preferred, where possible.
Identification of the problem or diagnosis, by name.

Partial dates are acceptable. If the subject of care is under the age of one year, then the complete date or a minimum of the month and year is necessary to enable accurate age calculations - for example, if used to drive decision support.
Estimated or actual date/time the diagnosis or problem was recognised by a healthcare professional.

If severity is included in the Problem/diagnosis name via precoordinated codes, this data element becomes redundant. Note: more specific grading of severity can be recorded using the Specific details SLOT.
An assessment of the overall severity of the problem or diagnosis.
Use to provide background and context, including evolution, episodes or exacerbations, progress and any other relevant details, about the problem or diagnosis.
Narrative description about the problem or diagnosis.

Use this data element to record precoordinated anatomical locations. If the requirements for recording the anatomical location are determined at run-time by the application or require more complex modelling such as relative locations then use the CLUSTER.anatomical_location or CLUSTER.relative_location within the 'Structured anatomical location' SLOT in this archetype. Occurrences for this data element are unbounded to allow for clinical scenarios such as describing a rash in multiple locations but where all of the other attributes are identical. If the anatomical location is included in the Problem/diagnosis name via precoordinated codes, this data element becomes redundant.
Record of a simple body site where the problem or diagnosis was located.
Identification of other diagnoses and problems that have a relationship to the diagnosis or problem recorded using this archetype instance.
Record as text, coded text or a link within the EHR.
Identification of the related problem or diagnosis.
Where no causality or sequence of events is known, this relationship type should be left blank.
The type of relationship that this problem or diagnosis has to the item.

Partial dates are acceptable. If the subject of care is under the age of one year, then the complete date or a minimum of the month and year is necessary to enable accurate age calculations - for example, if used to drive decision support.
Estimated or actual date/time of resolution or remission for this problem or diagnosis, as determined by a healthcare professional.

Use this SLOT to insert the CLUSTER.anatomical_location or CLUSTER.relative_location archetypes if the requirements for recording the anatomical location are determined at run-time by the application or require more complex modelling such as relative locations.
If the anatomical location is included in the Problem/diagnosis name via precoordinated codes, use of this SLOT becomes redundant.
Slot to contain detailed and structured anatomical location details.
This concept identifies the direct cause or causative agent of a Problem/Diagnosis. The concept includes the idea of complications, causative agent and due to.
This value identifies the sequence of events between the related items, but does not assert causality. This can be used for sequelae or late effects.

May include structured detail about the grading or staging of the diagnosis; diagnostic criteria, classification criteria or formal severity assessments such as Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events.
Details that are additionally required to record as unique attributes of this problem or diagnosis.

Use status or context qualifiers with care, as they are avariably used in practic and interoperability cannot be assured unless usage is clearly defined with the community of use. For example: active status - active, inactive, resolved, in remission; evolution status - initial, interim/working, final; temporal status - current, past; episodicity status - first, new, ongoing; admission status - admission, discharge; or priority status - primary, secondary.
Structured details for location-, domain-, episode- or workflow-specific aspects of the diagnostic process.
The problem or diagnosis does not interfere with normal activity or may cause damage to health if left untreated.
The problem or diagnosis causes interference with normal activity or will damage health if left untreated.
The problem or diagnosis prevents normal activity or will seriously damage health if left untreated.
Additional narrative about the problem or diagnosis not captured in other fields.
The date this problem or diagnosis was last updated.
For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
Narrative description about the course of the problem or diagnosis since onset.
The level of confidence in the identification of the diagnosis.
The diagnosis has been identified with a low level of certainty.
The diagnosis has been identified with a high level of certainty.
The diagnosis has been confirmed against recognised criteria.
Estimated or actual date/time that signs or symptoms of the problem/diagnosis were first observed.
A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.

To record the result of a laboratory test which may be used to record a single valued test but will often be specialised or templated to represent multiple value or 'panel' tests. This archetype also acts as the parent for specialisations appropriate for more specific laboratory tests microbiology, histopathology.

Specific identifier for this lab test. e.g. Full blood count , blood glucose, urine microbiology. May equate to the result name for a single value result. Commonly a coded term e.g from LOINC or SNOMED-CT.
Representations of the whole test in mutlimedia e.g image, audio, video.
Demographic details of the laboratory with responsibility for the test. Details of secondary laboratories may also be included.
This is an initial or interim result - further updates are anticipated.
This is the final result. No further alterations are anticipated.
This is a supplementary result ehich should be appended to a previous result.
This is a correction which should completely replace any previous results.
An overall interpretative comment on this test.
The local ID assigned to the order by the order requester. Equivalent to the Placer Order Identifier.
The local ID assigned to the test order by the order filler, usually by the (LIS) Laboratory Information System. Equivalent to the DICOM Accession Number and the Filler Order Identifier.
Details of the specimen being reported where all individual results are derived from the same specimen.
The identifier given to the laboratory test result of a pathology investigation.
The status of the lab test as a whole.
The test was aborted and never completed.
The date and time related to the results status is useful for version control and cumulative results for the report.
The date and/or time that the result was issued for the recorded test status.
The type of high-level diagnostic service e.g. biochemistry, haematology.
Slot to allow an annotation to be added to a particular test result at run-time.
Details of the clinician or organisation requesting the laboratory test.
Findings observed during the physical examination of a subject of care.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.

May be used to record a narrative summary of the complete clinical examination or key aspects of clinical examination findings, which will be supported by structured data. Details of specific structured findings can be included using CLUSTER archetypes in the 'Examination Detail' slot. This data element may be used to capture legacy data that is not available in a structured format.
Narrative description of the overall findings observed during a physical examination of a patient.

Detailed clinical findings will be recorded as CLUSTER archetypes which can be nested within this SLOT to represent the fractal nature of clinical examination and allow for variation in clinician's requirements for examination documentation. For example: CLUSTER.palpation_of_uterus, CLUSTER.palpation_of_cervix and CLUSTER.palpation_of_fetus can be nested in this slot or within each other to represent the specific requirements of clinicians working in the obstetric domains - content, priorities and level of detail will differ depending on clinical context, professional background and specialty.
Structured details of the physical examination.
Coding with a terminology is preferred, if possible. For example, 'normal examination' or 'tympanic membrane perforation'.
Single word, phrase or brief description which represents the clinical meaning and significance of the physical examination findings.
Description of any incidental factors that may have contributed to the physical examination findings.
Details about any device used during the physical examination.
Additional narrative about the overall physical examination findings not captured in other fields.
e.g. Local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
Record the findings and interpretation of an imaging examination, or series of examinations, performed.

Identification of the imaging examination or procedure performed, typically including modality and anatomical location (including laterality). Coding with a terminology, potientially a pre-coordinated term specifying both modality and anatomical location, is desirable where possible. Possible candidate terminologies: LOINC, SNOMED CT or RadLex.

The imaging method used to perform the examination e.g Ultrasound, CT, X-ray. Coding with a terminology is desirable, where possible. If the modality is specified by a code in the Examination result name, then this field is not required.

Details of the anatomical site of imaging examination, including laterality, if all individual findings and results are related to the same anatomical location. If the anatomical site is sufficiently specified with a code in the Examination test name, then this additional data is not required. Finer-grained multiple anatomical sites may be represented per Result group.
The status of the examination result as a whole.
Narrative description of findings, including comparative findings.
This is an initial or interim result: data may be missing or verification not been performed.
The result is complete and verified by the responsible radiologist.
The result has been modified subsequent to being Final, and is complete and verified by the radiologist.
The result is not available because the examination was not started or completed.
Description of clinical information available at the time of interpretation of results, and which may a link to the original clinical information provided in the examination request.

A group of structured results. Results may be grouped by anatomical location or by some other name or code to describe what binds all the results together. If a name or code is used, it is provided by run-time re-naming of the 'Result group' element or may be fixed in a specialised archetype or template. Coding with a terminology, potentially a pre-coordinated term including specimen type, is preferred where possible for the name. Should be coded with LOINC or SNOMED CT.

Specific detailed result, including both the value of the result item and additional information that may be useful for clinical interpretation. Results include whatever specific data items imaging services report as part of the clinical service; it may include measurements. These are often referred to as 'Structured Findings'. The result is identified by run-time re-naming of the 'Result group' element or may be fixed in a specialised archetype or template. Coding with a terminology, potentially a pre-coordinated term including specimen type, is preferred where possible for the name. Should be coded with LOINC or SNOMED CT. Examples include cardiac ejection fraction or bone density.
Actual value of the result. Most result values will be numerical measurements, but others may be coded concepts or free text.
May include statements about significant, unexpected or unreliable values, or information about the source of the value where this may be relevant to the interpretation of the result.
Details about the individual anatomical location to which these Result group examination results refer, where finer-grained representation of Anatomical location is required.
Single word, phrase or brief description representing the 'Conclusion'. Coding with a terminology is preferred, where possible.
Concise and clinically contextualised narrative interpretation of the imaging examination findings.
Rich text representation of the entire result as issued by the diagnostic service. Multiple formats are allowed but they must be semantically equivalent.

Additional narrative about the examination not captured in other fields. For example, recommendations for future examinations; a comment on appropriateness of the examination or on quality of images, if separate to findings; or a note that the film was given to the patient.
The date and/or time that the result was issued for the recorded 'Examination result status'.
Demographic details about the receiving imaging service performing the imaging test.

Details concerning a single examination requested. Note: Usually there is one examination request for each result, however in some circumstances multiple examination requests may be represented using a single Imaging examination result archetype.
The local identifier assigned to the order by the order requester. Equivalent to the HL7 Placer Order Identifier.
Identification of imaging examination or procedure requested, where the examination requested differs from the examination actually performed.
Details about the clinician or organisation requesting the imaging examination.
The local identifier assigned to the examination order by the order filler, usually by the Radiology Information System (RIS). Usually equivalent to the HL7 Filler Order Number.
Unique identifier of this study allocated by the imaging service.
The local identifier given to the imaging examination report.

Images referred to, or provided, to assist clinical understanding of the examination. If attached image is in DICOM format, all the fields below should be populated so the values are available to software that does not process DICOM images.
Unique identifier of this image allocated by the imaging service (often the DICOM image instance UID).
Unique identifier of this series allocated by the imaging service.
The name of the imaging view e.g Lateral or Antero-posterior (AP). Coding using a terminology is desirable, where possible.
Description of the subject of care's positon when the image was performed.
Specific date/time the imaging examination was performed.
An attached or referenced image of a current view.
Additional structured details of imaging examination methodology followed. For example, structured details about the examination technique, prepraration or contrast medium used.
Details of previous images used for comparison.
A subtype of the histopthological result.
A single set of macroscopic pathology findings.
Narrative text recorded at the time of specimen macroscopic dissection.
Details of the macroscopic specimen being reported.
Further structured detail concerning macroscopic findings
Single set of microscopic pathology findings. Usually equates to a single specimen.
Narrative text recorded at the time of specimen microscopic examination.
Further structured detail of microscopic findings, often disease or organ specific.
Macroscopic findings - more than one set of findings may be recorded.
Microscopic findings - more than one set of findings may be recorded.
General comment or description about macroscopy findings.
General comment or description about microscopy findings as a whole.
Confirmation, or otherwise, that the tissue or structure referred to by this macroscopic finding is present in the specimen for analysis.
The anatomical structure or tissue is present.
The anatomical structure or tissue is absent
Details of pathological staging, particularly for malignancy.
Details of size of one or more components of a single microscopy report e.g details of one or more tumour locations within a single tissue such as lung
Details of the size or other physical properties of the microscopic finding.
Details of the anatomical location of the microscopic finding being described.

To record the result of a laboratory test which may be used to record a single valued test but will often be specialised or templated to represent multiple value or 'panel' tests. This archetype also acts as the parent for specialisations appropriate for more specific laboratory tests microbiology, histopathology.

Specific identifier for this lab test. e.g. Full blood count , blood glucose, urine microbiology. May equate to the result name for a single value result. Commonly a coded term e.g from LOINC or SNOMED-CT.
Representations of the whole test in mutlimedia e.g image, audio, video.
Unique identifiers used in delivery of the care process.
Demographic details of the laboratory with responsibility for the test. Details of secondary laboratories may also be included.
This is an initial or interim result - further updates are anticipated
This is the final result. No further alterations are anticipated
This is a supplememtary result in addition to the Interim result
This is a Correction which should replace any previous results
An overall interpretative comment on this test.
The ID assigned to the order by the order requester. Equivalent to the NEHTA Requester Order Identifier.
The ID assigned to the test order by the order filler, usually by the (LIS) Laboratory Information System. Equivalent to the DICOM Accession Number and NEHTA Laboratory Request Identifier.
Details of the specimen being reported where all individual results are derived from the same specimen
The identifier given to the laboratory test result of a pathology investigation.
The status of the lab test as a whole.
The date and time related to the results status is useful for version control and cumulative results for the report.
The date and/or time that the result was issued for the recorded test status.
The type of high-level diagnostic service e.g. biochemistry, haematology.
Conclusions or 'pathological diagnoses' for the whole test.
A conclusion or 'pathological diagnosis' for this individual microscopic finding.
Slot to allow an annotation to be added to a particular test result at run-time. Generally unused in this specialisation.
Findings observed during the physical examination of a subject of care.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.

May be used to record a narrative summary of the complete clinical examination or key aspects of clinical examination findings, which will be supported by structured data. Details of specific structured findings can be included using CLUSTER archetypes in the 'Examination Detail' slot. This data element may be used to capture legacy data that is not available in a structured format.
Narrative description of the overall findings observed during a physical examination of a patient.

Detailed clinical findings will be recorded as CLUSTER archetypes which can be nested within this SLOT to represent the fractal nature of clinical examination and allow for variation in clinician's requirements for examination documentation. For example: CLUSTER.palpation_of_uterus, CLUSTER.palpation_of_cervix and CLUSTER.palpation_of_fetus can be nested in this slot or within each other to represent the specific requirements of clinicians working in the obstetric domains - content, priorities and level of detail will differ depending on clinical context, professional background and specialty.
Structured details of the physical examination.
Coding with a terminology is preferred, if possible. For example, 'normal examination' or 'tympanic membrane perforation'.
Single word, phrase or brief description which represents the clinical meaning and significance of the physical examination findings.
Description of any incidental factors that may have contributed to the physical examination findings.
Details about any device used during the physical examination.
Additional narrative about the overall physical examination findings not captured in other fields.
e.g. Local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
The patient is fully active, able to carry on all pre-disease performance without restriction.
The patient is fully restricted in physically strenuous activity but ambulatory and able to carry out work of a light or sedentary nature, e.g., light house work, office work.
The patient is ambulatory and capable of all selfcare but unable to carry out any work activities. Up and about more than 50% of waking hours.
The patient is capable of only limited selfcare, confined to bed or chair more than 50% of waking hours.
The patient is completely disabled. Cannot carry on any selfcare. Totally confined to bed or chair.
A framework for the classification and grading of malignancies using the TNM classification system.
Clinical TNM pre-treatment classification based on physical examination, imaging and biopsies.
Clincal assessment of the primary tumour.
Clinical assessment of the regional lymph nodes.
Pathological staging. Based on the clinical staging, results of procedures and pathological/histo-pathological assessment.
Pathological assessment of the primary tumour.
Pathological assessment of the regional lymph nodes.
The overall Clinical staging derived from each T, N and M component e.g T1aM0NX. May include additional TNM descriptors.
The overall Pathological staging derived from each pT, pN and pM component. May include additional TNM descriptors.
A text comment on the Clinical staging.
A text comment on the Pathological staging.
Clinical assessment of post-treatment residual tumour.
Presence of residual tumour cannot be assessed.
Pathological assessment of post-treatment residual tumour.
Presence of residual tumour cannot be assessed.
Grade of differentiation cannot be assessed.

Clear delineation between the scope of a problem versus a diagnosis is not easy to achieve in practice. For the purposes of clinical documentation with this archetype, problem and diagnosis are regarded as a continuum, with increasing levels of detail and supportive evidence usually providing weight towards the label of 'diagnosis'.
Details about a single identified health condition, injury or issue which impacts on the physical, mental and/or social well-being of an individual.
Coding of the name of the problem or diagnosis with a terminology is preferred, where possible.
Identification of the problem or diagnosis, by name.

Partial dates are acceptable. If the subject of care is under the age of one year, then the complete date or a minimum of the month and year is necessary to enable accurate age calculations - for example, if used to drive decision support.
Estimated or actual date/time the diagnosis or problem was recognised by a healthcare professional.

If severity is included in the Problem/diagnosis name via precoordinated codes, this data element becomes redundant. Note: more specific grading of severity can be recorded using the Specific details SLOT.
An assessment of the overall severity of the problem or diagnosis.
Use to provide background and context, including evolution, episodes or exacerbations, progress and any other relevant details, about the problem or diagnosis.
Narrative description about the problem or diagnosis.

Use this data element to record precoordinated anatomical locations. If the requirements for recording the anatomical location are determined at run-time by the application or require more complex modelling such as relative locations then use the CLUSTER.anatomical_location or CLUSTER.relative_location within the 'Structured anatomical location' SLOT in this archetype. Occurrences for this data element are unbounded to allow for clinical scenarios such as describing a rash in multiple locations but where all of the other attributes are identical. If the anatomical location is included in the Problem/diagnosis name via precoordinated codes, this data element becomes redundant.
Record of a simple body site where the problem or diagnosis was located.
Identification of other diagnoses and problems that have a relationship to the diagnosis or problem recorded using this archetype instance.
Record as text, coded text or a link within the EHR.
Identification of the related problem or diagnosis.
Where no causality or sequence of events is known, this relationship type should be left blank.
The type of relationship that this problem or diagnosis has to the item.

Partial dates are acceptable. If the subject of care is under the age of one year, then the complete date or a minimum of the month and year is necessary to enable accurate age calculations - for example, if used to drive decision support.
Estimated or actual date/time of resolution or remission for this problem or diagnosis, as determined by a healthcare professional.

Use this SLOT to insert the CLUSTER.anatomical_location or CLUSTER.relative_location archetypes if the requirements for recording the anatomical location are determined at run-time by the application or require more complex modelling such as relative locations.
If the anatomical location is included in the Problem/diagnosis name via precoordinated codes, use of this SLOT becomes redundant.
Slot to contain detailed and structured anatomical location details.
This concept identifies the direct cause or causative agent of a Problem/Diagnosis. The concept includes the idea of complications, causative agent and due to.
This value identifies the sequence of events between the related items, but does not assert causality. This can be used for sequelae or late effects.

May include structured detail about the grading or staging of the diagnosis; diagnostic criteria, classification criteria or formal severity assessments such as Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events.
Details that are additionally required to record as unique attributes of this problem or diagnosis.

Use status or context qualifiers with care, as they are avariably used in practic and interoperability cannot be assured unless usage is clearly defined with the community of use. For example: active status - active, inactive, resolved, in remission; evolution status - initial, interim/working, final; temporal status - current, past; episodicity status - first, new, ongoing; admission status - admission, discharge; or priority status - primary, secondary.
Structured details for location-, domain-, episode- or workflow-specific aspects of the diagnostic process.
The problem or diagnosis does not interfere with normal activity or may cause damage to health if left untreated.
The problem or diagnosis causes interference with normal activity or will damage health if left untreated.
The problem or diagnosis prevents normal activity or will seriously damage health if left untreated.
Additional narrative about the problem or diagnosis not captured in other fields.
The date this problem or diagnosis was last updated.
For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
Narrative description about the course of the problem or diagnosis since onset.
The level of confidence in the identification of the diagnosis.
The diagnosis has been identified with a low level of certainty.
The diagnosis has been identified with a high level of certainty.
The diagnosis has been confirmed against recognised criteria.
Estimated or actual date/time that signs or symptoms of the problem/diagnosis were first observed.
A suggestion, advice or proposal for current healthcare management or for future action.
Document to communicate information to others, commonly in response to a request from another party.
The status of the entire report. Note: This is not the status of any of the report components.
e.g. Local hospital departmental infomation or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Additional information required to capture local context or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
